sections.title: Election
sections.content_md:
*   **Election**: The **Speaker of the Lok Sabha** is elected by the House from among its own members, soon after the first meeting of the newly elected House.
*   **Term of Office**: Five years.
*   **Continuity**: The Speaker does not vacate office when the House is dissolved. They remain in office until a new Speaker is elected by the new Lok Sabha.
*   **Re-election**: Can be re-elected any number of times, provided they are elected as a member of the Lok Sabha.

sections.title: First Reading
sections.content_md:
**First Reading**: The first stage where a **Bill** is formally introduced in the House.

*   A **Minister** or **private member** introduces the **Bill**.
*   They give a speech explaining the **Bill's** objectives and merits.
*   The **Bill** is circulated.
*   **Cause-Effect**: If the House is in favour of the introduction, the **Bill** proceeds to the next stage.

sections.title: Ordinary Bills
sections.content_md:
*   **Ordinary Bill**: Can be introduced in either House of Parliament.
*   Can be introduced by a Minister (**Government Bill**) or a private member (**Private Member's Bill**).
*   **Reading**: The process of considering a bill.
*   A bill undergoes three **Readings** in each House.

sections.title: The Business of the House
sections.content_md:
**The Speaker**

*   Presides over House meetings; all speeches are addressed to the **Speaker**.
*   Allots time for discussion.
*   Interprets the rules of procedure; their decision on parliamentary matters is **final**.
*   Signs all **Bills** passed by the House before they go to the Rajya Sabha or the President.
*   Decides the admissibility of all questions, resolutions, and adjournment motions.
*   Puts issues to vote and announces results.
*   **Casting Vote**: Votes only when there are equal votes on both sides (a tie).
*   Decides whether a Bill is a **Money Bill** or not.

sections.title: Meaning of the Federalism
sections.content_md:
*   **Federalism**: A system of government where power is divided between a **central authority** and various **constituent units** of the country.
*   **Unitary Government**: In contrast, a system with only one level of government where sub-units are subordinate to the Central Government.
*   **Key Features of a Federal System**:
    *   Administrative powers are divided between the **Central** and **State** governments.
    *   Both levels are **supreme** in their own spheres according to the **Constitution**.
    *   Both Central and State governments derive their authority from the **Constitution**, not from each other.
*   **India**: Has a federal system with a strong **unitary bias**.

sections.title: Sessions
sections.content_md:
### Sessions

*   A **session** is a formal period when both Houses of Parliament convene to conduct business, like passing legislation.
*   Summoned by the **President**.
*   **Rules**: Each House must meet at least twice a year. The interval between two consecutive sessions must be less than six months.

#### The Three Sessions
*   **Budget Session**: February-May
*   **Monsoon Session**: July-August
*   **Winter Session**: November-December

sections.title: A Strong Centre
sections.content_md:
* The Constitution of India provides for a **strong Centre**, a feature of unitary government.
* The **Seventh Schedule** defines the allocation of powers between the Union and States via three lists:
    * **Union List**: Exclusive power for the **Union Government** to legislate.
    * **State List**: Exclusive power for **State Governments** to legislate.
    * **Concurrent List**: Both Centre and States can legislate, but the **Central Government** has an overriding position.

sections.title: Question Hour
sections.content_md:
*   **Question Hour**: The first hour of every working day of the **Lok Sabha**, usually starting at 11 am.
*   **Purpose**: Reserved for members to ask questions, keeping the government's functioning open to scrutiny.
*   The **Speaker** has the authority to decide otherwise and cancel or alter the hour.

sections.title: Term
sections.content_md:
*   Normal term of the **Lok Sabha** is **five years**.
*   **Early Dissolution**: Can be dissolved by the **President** on the advice of the **Prime Minister** before the term expires.
*   **Extension during Emergency**: During a **proclamation of an emergency**, the term may be extended by **Parliament** for **one year at a time**.
*   A new **Lok Sabha** must be elected within **six months** after the **national emergency** is lifted.

sections.title: Second Reading
sections.content_md:
**Second Reading**
- A detailed discussion of the Bill takes place.
- Members from different parties express views and make suggestions.
- The Bill may be changed or amended during this stage.
- The Bill can be referred to a **committee** for careful study and to make recommendations.

sections.title: Third Reading
sections.content_md:
**Third Reading**:
- The Bill as a whole is put to a vote.
- It is passed by the House if it secures a **simple majority**.

sections.title: The Second House
sections.content_md:
*   The bill is sent to the **Second House**.
*   The same procedure is followed as in the first house.

sections.title: Presidential Assent
sections.content_md:
* After a Bill is passed by both Houses of Parliament, it is sent to the President for **assent**.
* If the President gives **assent**, the Bill becomes a **Law** or an **Act**.
* The President can withhold **assent** and return the Bill to Parliament for reconsideration.
* If Parliament passes the Bill a second time (with or without changes), the President **must** give **assent**.

sections.title: Deadlock Between the two Houses
sections.content_md:
- In case of a **deadlock** between the two Houses, the **President** calls a **joint-sitting**.
- The **Speaker of the Lok Sabha** presides over the meeting.
- Issues are decided by a **majority vote**.
- The will of the **Lok Sabha** typically prevails because its membership is almost double that of the **Rajya Sabha**.

sections.title: A Single Constitution for Union and States
sections.content_md:
*   India has a **single, common, and unified Constitution**.
*   This single constitution applies to both the **Union** (Centre) and the **States**.
*   Consequently, states in India have **no right** to create their own separate constitutions.

sections.title: Administrative Functions
sections.content_md:
### Administrative Functions of the Speaker

*   Receives all **petitions** and **documents** in the House.
*   Communicates the **decisions of the House** to concerned authorities.
*   Regulates admission of **visitors** and **Press correspondents** to the galleries.

sections.title: Composition
sections.content_md:
*   **Maximum Strength**: 550 members.
    *   **States**: Up to 530 members.
    *   **Union Territories**: Up to 20 members.
*   The **104th Constitutional Amendment Act** (January 2020) ended the nomination of **Anglo-Indians** to the Lok Sabha.
    *   **Reason**: The 70-year reservation period expired on January 25, 2020.
*   The number of members from a state is based on its **population**.
*   **Examples of Representation**:
    *   **Uttar Pradesh**: 80 members
    *   **Maharashtra**: 48 members
    *   **Delhi (UT)**: 7 members
    *   **Goa, Manipur, Meghalaya**: 2 members each
    *   **Mizoram, Nagaland, Sikkim**: 1 member each

sections.title: Removal
sections.content_md:
*   **Resignation**: The **Speaker** can resign by submitting a letter to the **Deputy Speaker**.
*   **Removal**:
    *   The **Speaker** can be removed by the **Lok Sabha**.
    *   **Method**: A resolution passed by a **majority of all the then members**.
    *   **Prerequisite**: A minimum of **fourteen days' notice** must be given before the resolution is moved.

sections.title: Federal Setup in India
sections.content_md:
### Nature of Indian Federalism
*   The Constitution of India establishes a **federal system of Government**, though the term '**federation**' is not explicitly used.
*   It is considered an indestructible union; states cannot secede, which is crucial for maintaining India's unity and integrity.
*   The system is suited for a large, diverse country to counter separatist and provincial forces.

### Tiers of Government
*   **Originally Two-Tier**: 
    1.  **Union government** (Centre)
    2.  **State governments**
*   **Third Tier Added Later**: Local self-government in the form of **Panchayats** and **Municipalities**.

### Division of Powers
*   **Power Distribution**: Legislative and administrative powers are divided between the Union and State governments.
*   **Asymmetric Federalism**: The Central government is more powerful than the States.
*   **Constitutional Limitations**: Neither the Centre nor the States can violate the limitations on their power as imposed by the Constitution.

### Key Features of the Federal Setup
*   **Supreme Court**: Stands as the head of the judiciary to safeguard the constitutional distribution of powers.
*   **Bicameral Legislature**: Comprises the **Lok Sabha** (House of the People) and the **Rajya Sabha** (Council of States).
    *   The **Rajya Sabha** mainly represents the interests of the States.
*   **Financial Distribution**: The Constitution provides for the distribution of revenue between the Centre and the States to ensure both have adequate financial resources to perform their duties.

sections.title: Types of Questions
sections.content_md:
### Types of Questions

*   **General Rules**:
    *   All questions are addressed to the **Chair**.
    *   Government is obliged to answer admitted questions.
    *   A **ten-day notice** is typically required.

*   **Starred Question**:
    *   Indicated by an asterisk (*).
    *   Requires an **oral answer** on the floor of the House.
    *   Allows for **supplementary questions** after the Minister's reply.

*   **Unstarred Question**:
    *   Answer is given in **written form**.
    *   **No supplementary questions** are allowed.

*   **Short Notice Question**:
    *   Relates to a matter of **urgent importance**.
    *   Notice is **shorter than ten days**.
    *   The concerned Minister must agree to answer it at short notice.

sections.title: Money Bills
sections.content_md:
### Money Bills

*   **Certification**: The **Speaker of the Lok Sabha** rules whether a bill is a **Money Bill**.
*   **Introduction**:
    *   Requires prior consent of the **President of India**.
    *   Can *only* be introduced in the **Lok Sabha**.
*   **Role of the Rajya Sabha**:
    *   Receives the bill after it is passed by the **Lok Sabha**.
    *   Cannot reject a **Money Bill**.
    *   Must return the bill within **14 days**, with or without recommendations.
*   **Power of the Lok Sabha**:
    *   Can accept or reject any/all of the **Rajya Sabha's** recommendations.
    *   The **Lok Sabha** is the final authority on **Money Bills**.
*   **Deemed Passage**: If the **Rajya Sabha** does not return the bill in **14 days**, it is considered passed by both houses.
*   **Final Step**: The bill is sent to the **President** for assent.

sections.title: Quorum
sections.content_md:
*   **Quorum**: The minimum number of members required to be present in the House to transact business.
*   **Requirement**: One-tenth (1/10th) of the total membership of the **Lok Sabha** or the **Rajya Sabha**.
*   **Consequence**: Without a quorum, the House cannot conduct proceedings (e.g., pass Bills, resolutions).
*   **Action**: The **Speaker** may adjourn the House or suspend the meeting until the quorum is met.

sections.title: Deputy Speaker
sections.content_md:
**Deputy Speaker**

- **Function**: Performs the duties of the **Speaker** when the office is vacant or the **Speaker** is absent.
- **Election & Removal**: Elected and removed in the same manner as the **Speaker**.

sections.title: Disciplinary Functions
sections.content_md:
The **Speaker** is responsible for maintaining order and discipline in the House.

### Key Disciplinary Powers:
*   Orders unruly members to withdraw.
*   **Suspends** members for disregarding the authority of the Chair.
*   **Adjourns** the House in cases of grave disorder.
*   Orders indecent or unparliamentary words to be **expunged** (removed) from the proceedings.
*   Decides on cases related to a **breach of privilege** or **contempt of the House**.
*   Makes the final decision on member disqualification under the **Anti-Defection Law**. The Constitution states this decision is final and not subject to court jurisdiction.

sections.title: Questions
sections.content_md:
- Members of the House can ask the Government questions on matters of public interest.
- This right is known as **interpellation**.

sections.title: Flexibility of the Constitution
sections.content_md:
*   The **Constitution of India** is considered **flexible**.
*   Unlike other **federations** where **amendments** require consent from the **units**, the Indian **Parliament** can amend most provisions single-handedly.
*   Methods of amendment include:
    *   **Simple majority**
    *   **Two-thirds majority**

sections.title: Qualifications for Membership
sections.content_md:
### Qualifications for Membership (Lok Sabha)
- Must be an **Indian citizen**.
- **At least 25 years of age**.
- Name must be on the **electoral rolls** in some part of the country.
- Must not be **insolvent** (i.e., in debt and unable to meet financial commitments).
- Must not hold any **office of profit** under the government.
- Must not be a **proclaimed criminal**.
- Must not be of **unsound mind**.

sections.title: Important Features of Federalism
sections.content_md:
### Important Features of Federalism

*   **Multiple Tiers of Government**: Two or more levels of government (e.g., central, state) govern the same citizens.
*   **Separate Jurisdiction**: Each level has its own **jurisdiction** (legal authority) in specific matters of legislation, administration, and taxation, as specified in the **Constitution**.
*   **Constitutional Rigidity**: Fundamental provisions of the **Constitution** cannot be unilaterally changed by one level of government; such changes require the consent of both levels.
*   **Judicial Umpire**: **Courts** settle disputes between different levels of government regarding the exercise of their powers.
*   **Financial Autonomy**: Sources of revenue for each level are clearly specified to ensure their financial independence.

sections.title: Parliamentary Committees
sections.content_md:
### Speaker's Role in Parliamentary Committees

*   Acts as the **ex-officio Chairman** of certain committees, such as:
    *   **Business Advisory Committee**
    *   **Rules Committee**
*   Appoints the **Chairmen** of all other House committees.
*   Issues directions to **Chairmen** regarding their work and procedures.

sections.title: Non-Federal or Unitary Features
sections.content_md:
The Indian Constitution contains **non-federal** or **unitary features**.

*   **Effect**: This has led critics to describe it as "**federal in form but unitary in spirit**".

sections.title: Disqualification of Membership
sections.content_md:
### Disqualification of Membership

A person is disqualified from being a member of either House of Parliament if they:
*   Hold any **office of profit** under the Government of India or a State (exceptions include Ministers and offices exempted by Parliament).
*   Are of **unsound mind** and declared so by a competent court.
*   Are an **undischarged insolvent**.
*   Are not a **citizen of India**, have acquired foreign citizenship, or have an allegiance to a foreign power.
*   Are disqualified by or under any **law made by Parliament**.

**Decision-Making:**
*   If a question of disqualification arises, the **President's decision** is final.
*   The President must act in accordance with the opinion of the **Election Commission**.

**Penalty:**
*   A penalty may be imposed on a person who sits or votes in Parliament knowing they are disqualified.

sections.title: Zero Hour
sections.content_md:
### "Zero Hour"

- **Definition**: The period from 12 PM (immediately after the **Question Hour**) until the lunch break at 1 PM.
- **Function**: Members can raise all types of questions without any permission or prior notice.
- **Control**: The **Presiding Officer** manages the House during what can be a period of heated discussions, charges, and constant interruptions.

sections.title: Single Citizenship
sections.content_md: *   **Single Citizenship**: The **Indian Constitution** provides for a single citizenship for **India**, common to all people regardless of their **State** or **Union Territory**.

sections.title: Inequality of Representation in the Rajya Sabha
sections.content_md:
*   The **Indian Constitution** does not provide equal representation to states in the **Rajya Sabha**.
*   Representation is based on **population**, meaning more populous states have more representatives.
*   **Cause-Effect**: A state's population size determines its number of representatives.
*   Additionally, **12 members** are **nominated by the President** based on expertise in **art, literature, science, and social services**.
*   This system is considered a departure from the pure **federal principle** of equal state representation.

sections.title: Existence of Union Territories
sections.content_md:
**Union Territories**

*   A feature indicating the **unitary character** of the Indian Constitution.
*   These administrative units are directly governed by the **Central Government**.
*   They do not possess **independent powers or autonomy**.

sections.title: THE UNION PARLIAMENT
sections.content_md:
### The Union Parliament

*   The **Union Legislature** comprises the **President** and the two Houses of Parliament.
*   The two Houses are:
    *   **The Lok Sabha** (House of the People)
    *   **The Rajya Sabha** (Council of States)
*   **Parliament**: The body of people's representatives with supreme power of governance.
*   India is a **representative democracy**, where people exercise sovereign power through their elected representatives.

sections.title: Vacation of Seats
sections.content_md:
### Vacation of Seats

A member's seat in either House of Parliament becomes vacant in the following cases:

*   **Resignation:** If a member resigns by writing to the **Speaker** or **Chairman**.
*   **Absence:** If a member is absent from all meetings for a period of **60 days** without the House's permission.
    *   *Note:* This period does not count any time the House is **prorogued** or **adjourned** for more than four consecutive days.
*   **Disqualification:** If a member becomes subject to any **disqualifications** specified in the Constitution or an Act of Parliament.
*   **Dual Membership:** If a person elected to **Parliament** is already a member of a **State Legislature**, they must vacate their state seat (or vice versa).
*   **Defection:** If a person is disqualified under the **Anti-Defection Law**. This happens if a member:
    *   Voluntarily gives up the membership of their party.
    *   Votes against the direction of their party.

sections.title: Miscellaneous Functions
sections.content_md:
*   Presides over **joint sessions** of both Houses of Parliament.
*   Nominates personnel for **Parliamentary Delegations** to various countries, in consultation with the **Chairman of the Rajya Sabha**.
*   Presides over the **Conference of Presiding Officers** of legislative bodies in India.

sections.title: Motion
sections.content_md:
**Motion**:

- A formal proposal by a member for the House to take up a matter of public importance.
- **Purpose**: To draw the Government's attention to an issue and prompt suitable action.

sections.title: Adjournment Motion
sections.content_md:
**Adjournment Motion**

*   **Definition**: A proposal to lay aside all other business to discuss a **'definite matter of urgent importance'**.
*   **Effect**: Interrupts the normal business of the House.
*   **Examples of allowed subjects**:
    *   A railway accident with several deaths.
    *   A daring dacoity.
    *   Natural calamities (e.g., devastating floods, tornadoes).
    *   Communal tension.

sections.title: Lok Sabha
sections.content_md:
**Lok Sabha**
* Also known as the **House of the People**.
* Members are **directly elected** by the people of India.

sections.title: Parliamentary Procedures
sections.content_md:
### Parliamentary Procedures
*   **Parliamentary Procedures**: Formalities observed by legislators in Parliament and State Legislatures.

sections.title: No-Confidence Motion
sections.content_md:
### No-Confidence Motion

*   **Definition:** A proposal moved by the **Opposition** to express a lack of confidence in the ruling government.
*   **Constitutional Basis:** The **Council of Ministers** is collectively responsible to the **Lok Sabha**.
*   **Procedure:**
    *   Requires the support of at least **50 members** to be introduced.
    *   Must be discussed within **10 days** after leave is granted by the House.
*   **Outcome:** If the **No-Confidence Motion** is passed, the **Government has to resign**.
*   **Related Term:** A **Confidence Motion** is the reverse, often moved by the government to prove its majority.
*   **Historical Example:** In the **12th Lok Sabha**, the government led by **Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee** lost a **Confidence Motion** by one vote, causing the government to collapse.

sections.title: The No-Confidence Motions of the Past
sections.content_md:
*   **Since 1952**: 28 **No-Confidence Motions (NCM)** have been moved.
    *   27 were defeated by the government in power.
    *   **1979 Exception**: PM **Morarji Desai** resigned before the NCM vote could begin.
*   **Notable Records**:
    *   **Indira Gandhi**: Faced the most NCMs (15), all were defeated.
    *   **Lal Bahadur Shastri**: Faced the most NCMs per year of office.
    *   **Narasimha Rao**: Won an NCM with the narrowest margin.
*   **Recent Motion**: On **July 26, 2024**, an NCM submitted by Gaurav Gogoi against the **Narendra Modi** government was accepted.
*   **Important Distinction**: Thrice, governments have fallen during a **Vote of Confidence**, which is a different procedure from an NCM.

sections.title: Adjournment and Prorogation of the House
sections.content_md:
*   **Adjournment**: The suspension of a sitting of the House. Power rests with the **Speaker** or **Chairman**.
*   **Prorogation**: The termination of a session of Parliament. Power belongs to the **President**.

**Reasons for Adjournment:**
*   Daily business is concluded.
*   Death of a sitting/ex-member.
*   Disorder in the House.
*   Lack of **quorum**.
*   At the Speaker's discretion.

**Adjournment Sine Die**:
*   **Definition**: Suspension of a session for an indefinite period (Latin: 'without a date').
*   **Power**: The **Speaker** declares it when a session's business is complete.

sections.title: Anti-Defection Law
sections.content_md:
### Anti-Defection Law

*   Introduced by the **Constitutional Act (52nd Amendment) 1985**.
*   Added the **10th Schedule** to the Constitution.
*   Provides for disqualification of members of Parliament and State Legislatures on grounds of **defection**.

#### Grounds for Disqualification

1.  **Elected Member (Party Candidate):**
    *   Voluntarily relinquishes membership of their political party.
    *   Votes or abstains from voting contrary to the party's direction.
2.  **Nominated Member (Party Member at time of nomination):**
    *   Voluntarily gives up party membership.
    *   Votes or abstains contrary to party direction.
3.  **Nominated Member (Not a Party Member at time of nomination):**
    *   Disqualified if they join any political party *after* the expiry of six months from taking their seat.
4.  **Independent Member:**
    *   Disqualified if they join any political party after their election.

#### Exceptions to Disqualification

*   **Split:** A group representing a faction from a split, if the group consists of not less than **one-third** of the members of the legislative party.
*   **Merger:** If a party merges with another, and not less than **two-thirds** of the members of the legislative party concerned have agreed to the merger.
*   **Presiding Officers:** A person elected as **Speaker, Deputy Speaker, Chairman, or Deputy Chairman** is not disqualified if they voluntarily leave their party after being elected to the office, and can rejoin it after ceasing to hold that office.

sections.title: Passing of Bills
sections.content_md:
*   **Bill**: A proposal for a law; a draft statute.
*   To become law, a **Bill** requires:
    1.  Approval of both **Houses of Parliament**.
    2.  Assent of the **President of India**.
*   **Types of Bills**:
    *   **Ordinary Bills**
    *   **Money bills**

sections.title: Speaker of the Lok Sabha
sections.content_md:
### Speaker of the Lok Sabha

*   The **presiding officer** of the **Lok Sabha**; conducts the business of the House.
*   **Key Roles & Responsibilities:**
    *   Maintains discipline in the House.
    *   Acts as a guardian of the rights and privileges of members.
    *   Once elected, must be impartial and not affiliated with any party.
*   **Authority & Powers:**
    *   In the **Table of Precedence**, ranks higher than all Cabinet Ministers except the Prime Minister.
    *   Answerable only to the House for the discharge of powers and functions.
    *   Rulings cannot be challenged in any court of law.

sections.title: ROLE AND FUNCTIONS OF THE SPEAKER
sections.content_md:
# Role and Functions of the Speaker

*   The role and functions of the **Speaker** can be categorized into several areas.
